name: Against Malaria Foundation
evidence_text: Distributes long-lasting insecticide-treated mosquito nets (LLINs) to prevent malaria transmission in vulnerable populations. Malaria kills approximately 600,000 people annually, mostly children under 5. Multiple high-quality randomized controlled trials have consistently found strong impact from net distributions. GiveWell estimates cost of approximately $5,500 per life saved (2022-2024 average). About $6 to provide one net that protects families while sleeping.
transparency_notes: Conducts extensive post-distribution monitoring to verify net usage and coverage. Publishes detailed distribution reports and monitoring data publicly.

name: Malaria Consortium
evidence_text: Delivers seasonal malaria chemoprevention (SMC) programs providing preventive antimalarial medicine to children under 5 during the four peak transmission months in Sahel countries. Multiple high-quality studies demonstrate strong impact. GiveWell estimates cost of approximately $4,000 per life saved (2022-2024 average). About $7 to protect a child from malaria for one season. Also implements programs to combat pneumonia and other diseases.
transparency_notes: Conducts high-quality ongoing monitoring of coverage and effectiveness. Shares detailed program data and evaluation results publicly.

name: Helen Keller International
evidence_text: Provides vitamin A supplementation programs to children under 5 in areas with high deficiency rates. Vitamin A deficiency affects approximately 28% of children in program areas, leaving them vulnerable to infections that can lead to blindness and death. Strong evidence base from multiple randomized controlled trials showing mortality reduction. Cost-effective intervention delivering twice-yearly vitamin A capsules through mass campaigns.
transparency_notes: Publishes program coverage data and participates in independent evaluations. Transparent about distribution challenges and lessons learned.

name: New Incentives
evidence_text: Provides conditional cash transfers to caregivers who bring infants to government clinics for routine childhood immunizations. Works to increase vaccination coverage and reduce preventable child deaths in northern Nigeria. Disburses small cash payments (approximately $11 total per infant) conditional on receiving all age-appropriate vaccines. Evidence from randomized controlled trial shows significant impact on immunization rates. Also works with government partners to improve vaccine supply chains.
transparency_notes: Tracks and publicly reports on vaccination rates and cash transfer delivery. Conducts regular monitoring and shares program data.

name: GiveDirectly
regions: Kenya Uganda Rwanda Malawi Mozambique DRC
evidence_text: Provides unconditional cash transfers via mobile money to people living in extreme poverty. Recipients can spend funds on their most pressing needs without restrictions. Multiple randomized controlled trials demonstrate positive impacts on consumption, assets, and psychological well-being. Also running historic 12-year Universal Basic Income study with 20,000+ participants in Kenya. Transfers delivered directly to recipients with minimal overhead. Average transfer size approximately $1,000 per household.
transparency_notes: Highly transparent organization publishing detailed financial data, impact studies, and operational metrics. Independent research widely available.

name: Evidence Action
regions: Kenya Uganda Malawi India Nigeria Pakistan
evidence_text: Operates four main programs: (1) Safe Water Now provides chlorine dispensers at water points serving over 10 million people, (2) Deworm the World supports school-based deworming reaching 280+ million children, (3) Equal Vitamin Access strengthens vitamin A programs, (4) Syphilis-Free Start screens pregnant women. All programs based on rigorous evidence and cost-effectiveness analysis. Focus on scaling proven interventions through government partnerships.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports with detailed program metrics, cost data, and monitoring results. Strong culture of measurement and transparency.

name: One Acre Fund
regions: Kenya Rwanda Tanzania Uganda Burundi Malawi Nigeria Zambia
evidence_text: Supplies smallholder farmers with financing, agricultural training, quality seeds, fertilizer, and market facilitation. Serves over 5 million farmers in sub-Saharan Africa. Randomized controlled trials show significant increases in yields (average 50% increase) and farm income. Farmers repay financing through harvest proceeds. Model includes extensive field officer support with average 1:150 officer-to-farmer ratio. Focus on sustainable agricultural intensification and climate adaptation.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed annual impact reports with program metrics and independent evaluations. Transparent financial reporting available.

name: Living Goods
evidence_text: Trains and supports community health workers (CHWs), primarily women, to deliver lifesaving medicines, health education, diagnoses, and products to millions. Focuses especially on preventing and treating leading causes of child deaths including malaria, pneumonia, and diarrhea. Randomized controlled trial in Uganda showed 27% reduction in under-5 mortality. CHWs equipped with smartphones for diagnostics, supply management, and supervision. Integrated Community Case Management approach.
transparency_notes: Shares monitoring data and evaluation results publicly. Participates in rigorous external evaluations and publishes findings.

name: Development Media International
evidence_text: Runs large-scale media campaigns using radio and other platforms to promote evidence-based health behaviors including maternal and child health, nutrition, hygiene, sanitation, sexual reproductive health, and early childhood development. Randomized controlled trial in Burkina Faso showed 10% reduction in under-5 mortality. Uses behavior change communication and social marketing principles to create engaging local-language programming. Reaches millions through radio broadcasts in low-income countries.
transparency_notes: Publishes impact evaluation results and shares campaign monitoring data. Transparent about methodology and behavior change measurement.

name: Fistula Foundation
evidence_text: Treats obstetric fistula, a devastating childbirth injury causing incontinence that leaves women isolated and ashamed. Supports surgery costs (average $450 per surgery), surgeon training, facilities equipment, community outreach to find patients, and post-surgery reintegration. Has funded over 75,000 fistula repair surgeries with 90%+ success rate. Works in Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Nigeria, Niger, Guinea, Malawi, and other countries. Holistic approach includes mental health support and vocational training.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed annual reports with surgery statistics, outcomes data, and financial information. Partner hospitals report regularly.

name: Fred Hollows Foundation
evidence_text: Restores sight through cataract surgeries, trachoma treatment, and comprehensive eye care services. Has restored sight to over 2.5 million people and delivered over 200 million doses of trachoma antibiotics. Works to eliminate trachoma (leading infectious cause of blindness) through SAFE strategy: Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvement. Also trains eye health professionals and strengthens health systems. Operates in over 25 countries focusing on Indigenous and underserved communities.
transparency_notes: Publishes comprehensive annual reports with detailed program statistics, financial data, and impact metrics.

name: Iodine Global Network
regions: Global with focus on low-income countries
evidence_text: Works to eliminate iodine deficiency, the most common preventable cause of brain damage in newborns. Promotes and supports universal salt iodization programs worldwide. Provides technical assistance to governments for implementing and monitoring iodization programs. Iodine deficiency affects 2 billion people globally and causes cognitive impairment, goiter, and pregnancy complications. Salt iodization is safe, effective, and costs less than $0.05 per person per year. Evidence shows significant improvements in cognitive outcomes.
transparency_notes: Publishes global iodine nutrition data and country program reports. Collaborates with WHO, UNICEF on monitoring.

name: Sanku Project Healthy Children
evidence_text: Installs dosifiers (automated fortification machines) in small-scale flour mills across Africa that add essential vitamins and minerals to flour. Addresses micronutrient deficiencies (iron, folic acid, zinc, B vitamins) in at-risk communities. Reaches over 5 million people through 3,500+ installed dosifiers. Cost-effective intervention (~$1 per person per year) with strong evidence base for fortification impact on anemia and neural tube defects. Focus on sustainable, scalable model with local mill partnerships.
transparency_notes: Publishes program reach data and mill monitoring statistics. Transparent about operational model and challenges.

name: Village Enterprise
evidence_text: Equips people in extreme poverty with entrepreneurship training, seed capital ($150 cash grant), business mentoring, and savings groups to start sustainable businesses. Targets ultra-poor households in rural areas. Randomized controlled trial showed 42% consumption increase persisting 4+ years. 83% of first-time entrepreneurs served are women. Provides 3-12 months of support for business groups (typically 3 people). Focus on sustainable livelihoods rather than temporary relief.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual impact reports with detailed outcome data from randomized evaluations. Transparent about program costs and effectiveness.

name: Educate Girls
evidence_text: Works to increase enrollment and improve learning outcomes for out-of-school girls in rural India. Uses community volunteers to mobilize parents and identify out-of-school children. Delivers supplementary remedial learning curriculum using Teaching at the Right Level methodology. Randomized controlled trial showed significant learning gains. Has enrolled 1.6 million+ out-of-school children. Focus on India's most educationally backward districts. Gender-transformative approach addressing social barriers to girls' education.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed annual reports with enrollment data, learning outcomes, and program metrics. External evaluations available.

name: Teaching at the Right Level Africa
evidence_text: Implements teaching approaches that instruct students based on their actual learning levels rather than age-based curriculum. Works across multiple African countries to improve foundational literacy and numeracy. Based on Pratham's proven methodology from India with extensive RCT evidence showing large learning gains. Partners with governments to integrate approach into national education systems. Uses volunteers and teachers to deliver catch-up classes. Cost-effective at approximately $10-15 per child per year.
transparency_notes: Shares evaluation results and implementation reports. Collaborates with J-PAL and other researchers for impact measurement.

name: Breakthrough Trust
evidence_text: Focuses on culture-based change in India addressing gender-based violence through school curriculum redesign and mass media campaigns. Works with government to integrate gender equality content into education for girls and boys aged 11-24. Taaron ki Toli program uses participatory sessions to shift attitudes about gender norms. Randomized evaluation showed reduced acceptance of violence and improved gender attitudes. Multi-platform approach including school programs, media campaigns, and community mobilization.
transparency_notes: Publishes program reports and evaluation findings. Transparent about methodology and behavior change outcomes.

name: CEDOVIP
evidence_text: Establishes and runs community-led programs (SASA!) focused on reducing intimate partner violence in Kampala and northern Uganda. Randomized controlled trial showed 52% reduction in physical partner violence. Uses community activism approach with activists engaging communities through local events, media, and conversations. Addresses power imbalances and harmful masculinity norms. Plans to scale throughout Uganda. SASA! methodology adapted globally in 25+ countries.
transparency_notes: Shares detailed program data and RCT results publicly. Collaborates with researchers for rigorous evaluation.

name: Unlimit Health
evidence_text: Works with Ministries of Health and Education in sub-Saharan Africa to control and eliminate schistosomiasis (snail fever) and soil-transmitted helminthiasis (intestinal worms). Supports mass drug administration programs primarily treating school-aged children. Deworming is highly cost-effective (~$1 per child treated) with evidence of improved health, nutrition, and educational outcomes. Reaches over 10 million children annually. Focus on sustainable government-led programs with technical support.
transparency_notes: Publishes treatment coverage data and program reports. Works within national health systems for transparency and accountability.

name: Seva Foundation
evidence_text: Provides comprehensive eye care services to underserved communities in over 20 countries across Asia, Africa, and the Americas. Focuses on restoring sight through cataract surgery (~$50 per surgery), treating trachoma, and preventing blindness. Has restored sight to over 5 million people. Trains eye care professionals and strengthens local health systems for sustainability. Community-based screening programs reach remote populations. 90%+ surgical success rates.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports with detailed surgical statistics, financial data, and program outcomes. External audits available.

name: Raising The Village
evidence_text: Partners with last-mile communities in sub-Saharan Africa to address ultra-poverty through holistic model increasing household income to over $2/day within 24 months. Combines livelihood development (livestock/agriculture), health interventions, savings groups, and education support. Data-informed approach with regular monitoring. Targets households living on <$0.50/day. Graduation model based on BRAC's proven approach with adaptations for East African context. Focuses on women-led households.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed program data and household outcome metrics. Transparent about cost-effectiveness and impact measurement.

name: Food4Education
evidence_text: Provides nutritious, low-cost school meals to children in Kenyan public schools through innovative co-investment model with local governments and communities. Evidence shows school feeding improves attendance, learning outcomes, and nutrition. Meals cost approximately $0.15 per child per day. Sustainable model with government partnerships. Focus on ensuring no child learns on an empty stomach. Uses local food sourcing to support local economies and ensure cultural appropriateness.
transparency_notes: Publishes enrollment data, meal coverage statistics, and partnership details. Financial reporting shows cost efficiency.

name: PATH
regions: Nigeria DRC Burkina Faso Mozambique Uganda
evidence_text: Supports ministries of health to integrate RTS,S and R21 malaria vaccines into national immunization programs. Provides technical assistance, training, and operational support for vaccine introduction. Malaria vaccines add to existing prevention tools (nets, chemoprevention). Evidence from clinical trials shows significant reductions in severe malaria and deaths. WHO recommended both vaccines for children in malaria-endemic areas. Focus on operational research and implementation science.
transparency_notes: PATH is established organization with strong track record in vaccine introduction. Publishes program reports and implementation data.

name: Innovations for Poverty Action
evidence_text: Conducts rigorous randomized controlled trials to identify effective anti-poverty solutions. Works with decision-makers to implement evidence-based programs. Has conducted 1,000+ evaluations in 50+ countries. Focus on testing innovations in health, education, agriculture, governance, and other sectors. Provides research support and technical assistance to governments and NGOs. Builds local research capacity. Evidence produced influences billions in development spending.
transparency_notes: Transparent research organization publishing all study results publicly. Pre-registration and open data practices.

name: Lead Exposure Elimination Project
evidence_text: Works on advocacy and policy change to eliminate lead exposure, particularly from lead paint, in low and middle-income countries. Creates permanent regulatory infrastructure to prevent exposure. Lead exposure causes cognitive impairment in children with no safe level. Paint regulation is highly cost-effective prevention. Works with governments to adopt and enforce lead paint laws. Estimated 800 million children globally exposed to lead. LEEP has contributed to lead paint regulations in 15+ countries.
transparency_notes: Publishes reports on advocacy progress and policy wins. Transparent about theory of change and impact pathways.

name: Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative
evidence_text: Supports countries in building governance infrastructure for extractive sectors (mining, oil, gas). Improves transparency, accountability, and oversight through multi-stakeholder approach. Evidence shows EITI reduces corruption and increases GDP in implementing countries. 57 countries participating. Focus on revenue disclosure, beneficial ownership, and contract transparency. Helps ensure natural resource wealth benefits citizens rather than elites.
transparency_notes: EITI reporting is highly transparent by design. All country reports and revenue data publicly available.

name: Catholic Relief Services
evidence_text: Provides humanitarian assistance, health services, and development programs in vulnerable communities worldwide. Large-scale implementer with operations in 80+ countries. Programs include nutrition, maternal health, agriculture, education, and emergency response. Strong on-the-ground presence and relationships with local communities. Faith-based organization serving all people regardless of religion. Reaches 120 million+ people annually. Focus on sustainable development and systems strengthening.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports with program data and financial information. External evaluations and audits conducted regularly.

name: JSI Research & Training Institute
evidence_text: Delivers public health programs and research in low and middle-income countries. Focus on maternal and child health, family planning, nutrition, malaria, HIV/TB, and immunization. Works to strengthen health systems and improve service delivery. Provides technical assistance to governments and implementing partners. Evidence-based approach with monitoring and evaluation expertise. Operates in 40+ countries. Emphasis on sustainable, locally-led solutions.
transparency_notes: Established organization with strong monitoring and evaluation practices. Publishes research and program reports.

name: ARMoR
evidence_text: Works to increase low and middle-income country access to next-line antibiotics for drug-resistant infections. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) causes 1.3 million deaths annually, disproportionately in LMICs. Identifies barriers to accessing effective drugs and develops solutions. Policy advocacy and market shaping activities. Extremely cost-effective given high AMR mortality. Focus on ensuring availability of essential medicines when first-line drugs fail.
transparency_notes: New organization with transparent theory of change and impact measurement approach. Publishes program updates.

name: Medicines Development for Global Health
evidence_text: Develops pharmaceuticals for neglected tropical diseases including moxidectin for onchocerciasis (river blindness). Focus on achieving WHO prequalification for new treatments. Onchocerciasis affects 21 million people, causing blindness and severe itching. Moxidectin shows promise as superior treatment to ivermectin. Product development partnership model. Addresses market failure where pharmaceutical companies don't invest in diseases of the poor.
transparency_notes: Clinical trial data and regulatory submissions published. Transparent development pipeline and milestones.

name: Center for Global Development
evidence_text: Conducts research on global development issues including why effective health interventions remain underfunded. Produces policy-relevant analysis to improve development policy and practice. Influential think tank shaping development discourse and policy. Research on aid effectiveness, health financing, education, migration, and climate. Works with policymakers to translate evidence into action. Focus on rigorous economic analysis and practical policy recommendations.
transparency_notes: Publishes all research openly. Transparent about funding sources and potential conflicts of interest.

name: Ansh Foundation
evidence_text: Implements kangaroo mother care (KMC) programs for low-birthweight and preterm newborns in India. KMC involves skin-to-skin contact and exclusive breastfeeding support. Strong evidence from multiple studies shows KMC reduces mortality by 40% in low-birthweight infants. Cost-effective intervention requiring minimal equipment. Trains healthcare workers and establishes KMC units in government hospitals. Addresses major cause of neonatal deaths in low-resource settings.
transparency_notes: Publishes program data on babies treated and outcomes. Collaborates with researchers for impact evaluation.

name: Population Services International
evidence_text: Delivers health products and services through social marketing and clinical service delivery in developing countries. Programs focus on malaria (nets, testing, treatment), HIV prevention, family planning, and child survival. Uses commercial sector approaches to create demand and supply for health products. Operates in 60+ countries. Large-scale implementer reaching hundreds of millions. Subsidized product distribution through private sector channels.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports with detailed program metrics and reach data. External evaluations available for major programs.

name: Results for Development
evidence_text: Works to improve health and education systems in low and middle-income countries through research, technical assistance, and policy advocacy. Focus on sustainable financing, efficiency, and equity in health systems. Supports governments in resource allocation and program design. Evidence-based approach with emphasis on data use for decision-making. Programs in health financing, primary care, immunization, and nutrition.
transparency_notes: Publishes research reports and policy briefs. Transparent about projects and partnerships with governments and donors.

name: IDinsight
evidence_text: Provides data-driven advisory services to development organizations and governments. Conducts rigorous impact evaluations, monitoring systems design, and decision support. Uses randomized controlled trials, surveys, and administrative data analysis. Works with governments, foundations, and NGOs to improve program effectiveness. Focus on actionable insights and decision-relevant research. Operates in India and multiple African countries. Builds local evaluation capacity.
transparency_notes: Transparent research practices with published evaluation reports. Maintains independence and methodological rigor.

name: Bandhan
evidence_text: Operates Targeting the Hardcore Poor (THP) program providing asset transfers, training, and support to ultra-poor women-led households in India. Provides livestock or other productive assets plus consumption support, skills training, savings facilitation, and regular coaching for 18-24 months. Randomized evaluation showed large sustained impacts on consumption, assets, and well-being. Cost approximately $400 per household. Model proven effective in multiple contexts (Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Ghana, India, Pakistan, Peru).
transparency_notes: Publishes program data and participates in rigorous external evaluations. Multiple RCTs demonstrate impact.

name: BRAC
evidence_text: Implements ultra-poor graduation programs providing asset transfers (e.g., livestock), skills training, consumption support, savings groups, and ongoing coaching to help extremely poor households achieve sustainable livelihoods. Pioneered graduation approach now replicated globally. Serves millions in Bangladesh and programs in Afghanistan, Philippines, Tanzania, Uganda, and others. Strong evidence base with multiple randomized evaluations. Comprehensive development organization also working in health, education, and financial inclusion.
transparency_notes: Large, established organization with extensive monitoring systems. Publishes detailed annual reports and evaluation results.

name: Dimagi
evidence_text: Develops CommCare, a mobile platform used by community health workers and frontline health workers to deliver services. Supports data collection, case management, decision support, and supervision. Used by 500,000+ frontline workers in 80+ countries. Improves quality and efficiency of health service delivery. Open-source platform adaptable to different contexts. Evidence shows improved health worker performance and service quality. Focus on low-resource settings.
transparency_notes: Transparent technology development with open-source approach. Publishes case studies and implementation reports.

name: Dispensers for Safe Water
evidence_text: Installs and maintains chlorine dispensers at community water points in rural areas, providing over 10 million people with access to safe drinking water. Chlorination at point of collection addresses water contamination. Evidence from randomized trials shows 25% reduction in under-5 mortality. Cost-effective at ~$1.50 per person per year. Community promoters encourage dispenser use and refill containers. High sustained usage rates. Prevents waterborne diseases including cholera and diarrhea.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed program data on dispensers installed, people reached, and usage rates. Regular monitoring and evaluation.

name: Deworm the World Initiative
evidence_text: Partners with governments to implement national school-based deworming programs treating children for intestinal worms. Reached over 280 million children with cost-effective treatments (~$0.50 per child). Strong evidence from randomized trials shows improved health, school attendance, and long-term earnings. Provides technical assistance, monitoring, and advocacy to government programs. Treats schistosomiasis and soil-transmitted helminths. Focus on sustainable government-led programs at scale.
transparency_notes: Extensive monitoring and evaluation with publicly available reports. Independent coverage surveys verify treatment delivery.

name: Sightsavers
cause: Eye health and neglected tropical diseases
evidence_text: Works to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote equal opportunities for people with disabilities in Africa and Asia. Programs include cataract surgery, trachoma elimination, onchocerciasis control, school-based deworming, and inclusive education. Treats millions annually through large-scale programs. Works with governments to strengthen eye health systems. Evidence-based interventions with strong track record. Reaches 34+ countries.
transparency_notes: Publishes comprehensive annual reports with detailed program statistics and financial data. External evaluations conducted.

name: Oxfam
evidence_text: Provides humanitarian aid, development programs, and advocacy to fight poverty and injustice worldwide. Programs focus on women's rights, climate justice, economic inequality, and emergency response. Large international confederation reaching millions. Works on systemic change through policy advocacy and grassroots organizing. Emergency response capacity in disasters and conflicts. Long-term development programs in agriculture, water, and livelihoods.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports and impact data. Independent evaluations of major programs available.

name: WaterAid
evidence_text: Provides access to clean water, sanitation, and hygiene education in the world's poorest communities. Works in 26 countries ensuring everyone has sustainable access to safe water and toilets. Evidence shows WASH interventions reduce diarrheal disease and improve health outcomes. Reached 28.5 million people with clean water in 2022-23. Community-led approach with government partnerships for sustainability. Also advocates for policy change and increased WASH funding.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed annual reports with reach data and program outcomes. External evaluations and impact assessments conducted.

name: Vitamin Angels
evidence_text: Provides essential vitamins and minerals to pregnant women, new mothers, and children under five in underserved communities worldwide. Focus on vitamin A and prenatal multivitamins to reduce malnutrition and preventable diseases. Reached 70+ million women and children in 2022. Works through network of local partners for distribution. Cost-effective intervention (~$1 per person per year). Evidence-based approach focused on populations with highest micronutrient deficiency.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual impact reports with reach data and distribution statistics. Financial transparency with low overhead.

name: Partners in Health
regions: Haiti Rwanda Liberia Sierra Leone Malawi Peru Navajo Nation
evidence_text: Delivers high-quality healthcare to the poorest communities globally through accompaniment model. Focus on comprehensive health systems strengthening including infrastructure, training, supply chains, and policy. Programs address HIV, tuberculosis, Ebola, maternal health, NCDs, and mental health. Pioneered community health worker model and treatment for drug-resistant TB. Works in solidarity with communities to achieve health equity. Long-term commitment to partners.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed program reports and health outcome data. Academic partnerships produce extensive research.

name: Pratham
evidence_text: Implements innovative education programs in India focusing on foundational literacy and numeracy. Teaching at the Right Level (TaRL) approach groups children by learning level rather than age/grade. Multiple randomized evaluations show large learning gains at low cost. Reaches millions of children annually. Uses community-based volunteers and camps. Cost-effective at ~$15 per child per year. Works with government to integrate approach into public schools. Largest education NGO in India.
transparency_notes: Extensive evaluation evidence from J-PAL and other researchers. Publishes annual reports with reach and learning outcome data.

name: Global Alliance for Improved Nutrition
evidence_text: Works to reduce malnutrition by improving quality, safety, and affordability of nutritious foods for vulnerable populations. Programs include food fortification (salt iodization, staple food fortification), biofortification, and food systems strengthening. Works with governments and private sector to scale nutrition interventions. Reaches 1 billion+ people through fortification programs. Evidence-based approach focusing on sustainable market-based solutions.
transparency_notes: Publishes impact reports and program data. Transparent about partnerships and funding sources.

name: International Rescue Committee
evidence_text: Provides emergency aid and long-term assistance to refugees and displaced people worldwide. Programs include health care, education, economic support, protection services, and emergency response. Operates in conflict and post-conflict settings. Reaches 30+ million people annually. Evidence-based programming with increasing focus on rigorous evaluation. Large-scale implementer with operational presence in hardest-to-reach areas. Combination of emergency relief and recovery programs.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports with program reach and outcome data. Increasing transparency through Airbel Impact Lab evaluations.

name: Mercy Corps
evidence_text: Helps people in the world's toughest places build secure, productive, and just communities through emergency response, economic development, and peacebuilding programs. Focus on fragile and conflict-affected settings. Programs in agriculture, financial inclusion, youth employment, climate adaptation, and humanitarian response. Reaches 23+ million people annually. Long-term commitment combining immediate relief with addressing root causes of poverty and conflict.
transparency_notes: Publishes annual reports with program data. Increasing use of randomized evaluations and impact measurement.

name: Helen Keller Intl Vitamin A
evidence_text: Delivers twice-yearly vitamin A supplementation campaigns to young children in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia. Prevents blindness, strengthens immune systems, and reduces child mortality. Cost-effective intervention reaching children during National Immunization Days and other health campaigns. Strong evidence base from multiple randomized trials. Integrates with existing health systems for sustainability and efficiency. Focus on countries with highest burden of vitamin A deficiency.
transparency_notes: Helen Keller publishes coverage survey data and program reports. Independent monitoring and evaluation conducted.

name: Malaria Consortium SMC
regions: Burkina Faso Chad Nigeria Togo Mali
evidence_text: Administers monthly courses of antimalarial drugs (sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine + amodiaquine) to children under 5 during the four months of peak malaria transmission in Sahel region. Prevents malaria illness and death during highest-risk period. Multiple RCTs demonstrate 75% reduction in malaria cases. Community drug distributors deliver door-to-door. Cost approximately $7 per child protected. GiveWell top-rated program with exceptionally strong evidence.
transparency_notes: Malaria Consortium conducts extensive monitoring including coverage surveys and pharmacovigilance. Data published annually.

name: Against Malaria Foundation ITNs
evidence_text: Procures and distributes long-lasting insecticide-treated nets (LLINs) to protect families from malaria-carrying mosquitoes while sleeping in high-burden countries. Nets provide both physical barrier and insecticide kills mosquitoes. Evidence shows 20% reduction in all-cause child mortality. Door-to-door distribution ensures universal coverage. Detailed pre- and post-distribution monitoring. Partners with national malaria programs. Cost approximately $6 per net including distribution.
transparency_notes: AMF has exceptional transparency including post-distribution check-ups at 6, 18, and 30 months. All data published.

name: New Incentives CCT
evidence_text: Disburses small cash payments (~$11 total per infant) to caregivers conditional on infants receiving all age-appropriate routine immunizations at government health clinics. Increases immunization coverage and reduces preventable child deaths. Randomized trial showed 26 percentage point increase in full immunization. Also works with government to improve vaccine supply chains and clinic quality. Mobile money platform for transparent cash delivery.
transparency_notes: New Incentives tracks vaccination rates, cash transfers delivered, and program costs. Regular monitoring and external evaluation.

name: Evidence Action Safe Water Now
evidence_text: Maintains chlorine dispensers at communal water points enabling households to treat water with proper chlorine dosage at collection. Reduces waterborne disease deaths including diarrhea, cholera, and typhoid. RCT evidence shows 25% reduction in under-5 mortality. Over 10 million people with access. Community promoters encourage usage and refill dispensers monthly. Sustainable model with high usage rates (75%+). Cost ~$1.50 per person per year.
transparency_notes: Evidence Action publishes detailed program metrics including dispensers operational, usage rates, and people reached.

name: Evidence Action Equal Vitamin Access
evidence_text: Works with governments to strengthen vitamin A supplementation programs ensuring coverage reaches the most vulnerable children. Addresses supply chain gaps, improves distribution systems, and builds government capacity. Complements direct service delivery organizations. Focus on system-level improvements for sustainable high coverage. Evidence-based approach to identifying and addressing bottlenecks. Cost-effective support to existing platforms.
transparency_notes: Publishes program monitoring data and coverage improvements. Transparent about system strengthening approach.

name: Evidence Action Syphilis-Free Start
evidence_text: Supports screening and treatment programs for maternal syphilis to prevent congenital syphilis transmission. Maternal syphilis causes stillbirths, neonatal deaths, and serious complications. Testing and treatment with penicillin is highly effective and cost-effective. Works within antenatal care systems to ensure pregnant women receive testing and treatment. Addresses testing kit stockouts and supply chain issues. WHO recommends universal screening but coverage remains low in many countries.
transparency_notes: Evidence Action tracks testing rates, treatment coverage, and program outcomes. Regular monitoring and reporting.

name: StrongMinds
evidence_text: Treats depression among women and adolescents in Africa through group interpersonal psychotherapy delivered by trained lay providers in community settings. Depression affects 1 in 5 women in Uganda. Evidence shows large sustained improvements in depression symptoms and well-being. Cost-effective at ~$100 per participant. 12-session group therapy model. Focus on task-shifting to lay providers for scalability. Also trains other organizations in methodology.
transparency_notes: Publishes outcome data from surveys and monitoring. Independent evaluation evidence available.

name: Possible
evidence_text: Delivers high-quality healthcare in rural Nepal through community health workers and rural hospitals. Addresses maternal health, child health, and infectious diseases in areas with limited access. Operates government-partnered hospitals providing free care. Community health worker program provides home-based care. Evidence shows significant improvements in health outcomes. Model demonstrates public-private partnership for rural health delivery. Focus on sustainable systems strengthening.
transparency_notes: Publishes detailed health outcome data and program reports. Academic partnerships produce research on model effectiveness.

name: Lwala Community Alliance
evidence_text: Partners with rural Kenyan communities to co-create health, education, and economic development solutions addressing root causes of poverty and poor health outcomes. Community health worker model plus clinic services. Programs in maternal health, child health, WASH, agriculture, and youth empowerment. Community-owned and community-led approach. Evidence of improved health indicators in catchment area. Focus on holistic, integrated development.
transparency_notes: Publishes program data and health outcome metrics. Transparent community partnership approach.

name: Nyaya Health
evidence_text: Provides comprehensive healthcare to remote communities in Nepal through hospitals, health posts, and community health worker programs. Focus on maternal and child health in underserved areas. Public-private partnership model with government. Free care for poorest community members. Strong community health worker network. Evidence of improved maternal and child health outcomes. Emphasis on health systems strengthening and sustainability.
transparency_notes: Publishes health outcome data and program reports. Transparent about costs and impact.

name: Last Mile Health
evidence_text: Strengthens community health systems by training and supporting community health workers to provide primary healthcare in hard-to-reach areas. Works with governments to professionalize CHW programs. Demonstrated impact on maternal and child health outcomes. Equipped CHWs provide diagnosis and treatment for common illnesses plus health promotion. Digital tools for supervision and supply chain. Focus on sustainable government-owned programs.
transparency_notes: Publishes implementation research and program data. Evidence from Liberia shows health improvements.

name: Riders for Health
evidence_text: Manages and maintains vehicles and motorcycles for health workers in rural Africa ensuring reliable transportation for delivering healthcare supplies and services. Addresses critical transport gap preventing health service delivery. Professional fleet management improves reliability and reduces costs. Enables vaccine delivery, supervision visits, and emergency transport. Focus on sustainable vehicle management systems. Works with governments and health NGOs.
transparency_notes: Publishes program data on vehicles managed and health services enabled. Transparent about operational model.

name: VillageReach
evidence_text: Strengthens health systems in remote areas through improved supply chains, health worker support, and technology solutions. Programs ensure access to essential medicines and vaccines. Operates human-centered design approach to identify and address system gaps. Works within government health systems. Programs in cold chain equipment, vaccine delivery, community health, and digital health. Evidence of improved service availability and health outcomes.
transparency_notes: Publishes program evaluations and implementation research. Transparent about system strengthening approach.

name: Project Healthy Children
evidence_text: Works with governments to implement large-scale food fortification programs adding essential vitamins and minerals to staple foods consumed by at-risk populations. Focus on flour, oil, and sugar fortification. Evidence shows fortification reduces anemia and prevents neural tube defects. Cost-effective population-level intervention. Provides technical assistance for fortification standards, monitoring, and enforcement. Sustainable government-led programs.
transparency_notes: Publishes program data on population coverage and fortification compliance. Works transparently with governments.

name: Vitamin A Supplementation Programs
evidence_text: Mass distribution campaigns providing high-dose vitamin A capsules to children aged 6-59 months twice annually. Reduces mortality from infectious diseases (measles, diarrhea, malaria) and prevents blindness. Multiple large RCTs show 12-24% reduction in all-cause child mortality. Delivered through National Immunization Days and other platforms. Cost-effective at ~$1-2 per child per year. WHO recommends in areas with vitamin A deficiency.
transparency_notes: Multiple organizations deliver VAS programs with monitoring data. Coverage surveys measure reach and equity.

name: Seasonal Malaria Chemoprevention Programs
evidence_text: Preventive antimalarial treatment administered monthly during peak transmission season (typically 4 months) to children under 5 in Sahel countries. Prevents severe malaria and death during highest-risk period. Strong evidence from multiple RCTs showing 75% reduction in malaria cases. WHO-recommended intervention. Community drug distributors deliver door-to-door with directly observed treatment. Complements other malaria interventions (nets, treatment).
transparency_notes: Programs monitored through coverage surveys and pharmacovigilance. Data on coverage, adherence, and adverse events collected.

name: Insecticide-Treated Net Distribution
evidence_text: Distribution of long-lasting insecticide-treated bed nets (LLINs) providing physical and chemical barrier against malaria-carrying mosquitoes. Nets effective for 2-3 years. Evidence shows approximately 20% reduction in all-cause child mortality and 50% reduction in malaria cases. Universal coverage campaigns with door-to-door distribution. WHO recommends one net per two people. Mass distribution supplemented by continuous distribution through antenatal and immunization services.
transparency_notes: National programs monitored through household surveys measuring coverage and usage. Post-distribution surveys verify delivery.

name: Conditional Cash Transfers for Immunization Programs
evidence_text: Small financial incentives provided to caregivers conditional on bringing children for all scheduled routine immunizations. Increases vaccine coverage and reduces preventable deaths from measles, pneumonia, diarrhea, and other diseases. Evidence from RCTs shows significant increases in immunization rates. Complements supply-side improvements. Cost-effective in low-coverage settings where access exists but demand is insufficient. Mobile money platforms enable transparent delivery.
transparency_notes: Programs track vaccination rates and cash transfer delivery. Independent verification of immunization through health records.

name: Mass Deworming Programs
regions: Endemic areas in Africa Asia Latin America
evidence_text: School-based administration of deworming medication (albendazole, mebendazole, praziquantel) to all children in endemic areas. Reduces worm burden from schistosomiasis and soil-transmitted helminths improving health, nutrition, and educational outcomes. WHO recommends periodic treatment in endemic areas without individual diagnosis. Cost-effective at ~$0.50-1 per child. Evidence shows improved school attendance and long-term earnings. Government-led programs with NGO support.
transparency_notes: National programs report treatment coverage. Independent coverage validation surveys conducted in many countries.

name: Safe Water Chlorination Programs
evidence_text: Point-of-collection chlorine dispensers enabling households to treat water with proper chlorine dosage. Reduces diarrheal disease and under-5 mortality. RCT evidence shows 25% mortality reduction in young children. Addresses contamination between source and consumption. Community-based distribution and promotion model. Sustainable with ongoing maintenance and refilling. Cost-effective at ~$1-2 per person per year. Complements protected water sources.
transparency_notes: Programs monitor dispenser functionality and usage rates. Water quality testing verifies chlorination effectiveness.

name: Unconditional Cash Transfer Programs
evidence_text: Direct one-time cash payments via mobile money to extremely poor households with no restrictions. Recipients invest in most pressing needs including food, housing, livestock, education, and business assets. Strong evidence from multiple RCTs shows positive impacts on consumption, assets, psychological well-being, and empowerment. No evidence of increased alcohol/tobacco spending. Cost-effective in extreme poverty contexts. Digital delivery minimizes transaction costs.
transparency_notes: Programs track transfer delivery and collect outcome data. Independent research evaluates impacts on multiple well-being dimensions.

name: Salt Iodization Programs
evidence_text: Addition of iodine to salt at production level preventing iodine deficiency disorders including brain damage in newborns, cognitive impairment in children, and goiter in adults. Iodine deficiency affects 2 billion people globally. Salt iodization is safe, effective, and costs less than $0.05 per person per year. Requires regulatory framework and monitoring. WHO and UNICEF recommend universal salt iodization. Demonstrated success in eliminating iodine deficiency in 100+ countries.
transparency_notes: Programs monitored through household salt iodine testing and population iodine nutrition surveys. Data reported to WHO.

name: Fortification of Staple Foods Programs
evidence_text: Adding essential vitamins and minerals (iron, folic acid, zinc, B vitamins) to commonly consumed foods like flour, rice, and cooking oil. Addresses micronutrient deficiencies at population level. Evidence shows fortification reduces anemia, prevents neural tube defects, and improves cognition. Cost-effective at pennies per person per year. Requires industry partnerships and regulatory enforcement. Mandatory fortification in 80+ countries. Focus on ensuring quality and coverage.
transparency_notes: National programs monitor fortification compliance through food sampling. Population surveys measure micronutrient status changes.

name: Community Health Worker Programs
evidence_text: Training and equipping local health workers to provide primary healthcare, education, and referrals in underserved communities. CHWs deliver diagnosis and treatment for common childhood illnesses (malaria, pneumonia, diarrhea), promote healthy behaviors, and link communities to health systems. Evidence shows improved access, utilization, and health outcomes. Cost-effective cadre for extending coverage. WHO recommends CHW programs for universal health coverage in resource-limited settings.
transparency_notes: CHW programs monitored through health information systems tracking service delivery. Supervision data and quality assessments conducted.

name: Obstetric Fistula Treatment Programs
evidence_text: Surgical repair of childbirth injuries (vesicovaginal or rectovaginal fistula) causing incontinence. Surgery combined with counseling and reintegration support. Affects 2+ million women globally, mostly in areas without access to cesarean sections. 90%+ success rate for fistula closure. Repairs restore dignity and enable women to return to families and communities. Cost approximately $450 per surgery including hospital stay and follow-up. Also includes prevention through improved obstetric care.
transparency_notes: Programs report surgical volumes, closure rates, and patient outcomes. Long-term follow-up data on quality of life improvements.

name: Trachoma Elimination Programs
evidence_text: Mass drug administration of azithromycin antibiotics combined with promotion of facial cleanliness and environmental improvement to eliminate trachoma, the leading infectious cause of blindness. Trachoma affects 137 million people in endemic areas. WHO SAFE strategy: Surgery for advanced disease, Antibiotics (azithromycin), Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvement (water/sanitation). Evidence shows elimination is achievable. 16 countries have eliminated trachoma as public health problem.
transparency_notes: Programs monitored through trachoma prevalence surveys. WHO validates elimination and certifies countries meeting criteria.

name: Cataract Surgery Programs
evidence_text: Provision of affordable, high-quality cataract surgery to restore sight in blind or visually impaired individuals. Cataracts are leading cause of blindness globally (15 million people). Surgery highly effective with 90%+ success rates. Cost approximately $25-100 per surgery in low-income settings. Outreach programs identify patients in remote areas. Intraocular lens implants provide permanent vision restoration. Training surgeons and strengthening eye care systems.
transparency_notes: Programs track surgical volumes, visual outcomes, and patient satisfaction. Quality audits ensure high success rates.

name: Smallholder Agriculture Support Programs
evidence_text: Provision of quality seeds, fertilizer, training, and financing to small-scale farmers. Increases crop yields (typically 50%+), farm income, and household food security. Evidence from RCTs shows significant economic impacts. Input financing repaid through harvest proceeds. Extensive field officer support with training on improved practices. Focus on staple crops (maize, beans) and sustainable intensification. Climate-smart agriculture approaches for resilience.
transparency_notes: Programs track farmer enrollment, yields, repayment rates, and income changes. Independent evaluations measure long-term impacts.

name: Ultra-Poor Entrepreneurship Programs
evidence_text: Business skills training combined with seed capital ($100-200) and ongoing mentorship helping extremely poor households start sustainable micro-enterprises. Evidence from multiple RCTs shows large sustained impacts on consumption, assets, and well-being. Forms business groups of 3 people for peer support. Provides 3-12 months of intensive support. Focus on women entrepreneurs (70-80% of participants). Cost-effective pathway out of extreme poverty.
transparency_notes: Programs collect detailed outcome data through surveys. Multiple rigorous RCTs demonstrate long-term impacts.

name: Gender-Based Violence Prevention Programs
evidence_text: Community education and social norm change programs addressing intimate partner violence and promoting gender equality through curriculum integration, mass media campaigns, and community mobilization. Evidence from RCTs shows reduced acceptance of violence and improved gender attitudes. Works with schools, communities, and media. Addresses harmful masculinity norms and power imbalances. Focus on primary prevention through culture change.
transparency_notes: Programs measure attitude and behavior changes through population surveys. RCT evidence demonstrates impacts.

name: Girls Education Enrollment Programs
evidence_text: Community mobilization and volunteer-led efforts to identify and enroll out-of-school girls in formal education. Addresses social and economic barriers to girls' education. Volunteers conduct door-to-door surveys, engage parents, and support enrollment. Combined with learning support to ensure retention. Evidence shows significant enrollment increases and learning improvements. Cost-effective at ~$50 per girl enrolled. Targets India's most educationally backward districts.
transparency_notes: Programs track enrollment numbers, retention rates, and learning outcomes. RCT evidence shows impact on enrollment and learning.

name: Remedial Learning Programs
evidence_text: Supplementary education interventions targeting children at their actual learning level rather than grade level. Helps struggling students catch up in foundational literacy and numeracy. Strong evidence from multiple RCTs showing large learning gains. Uses volunteers or teachers to deliver catch-up classes. Groups children by learning level for targeted instruction. Cost-effective at $10-20 per child per year. Proven approach from India now scaling in Africa.
transparency_notes: Programs measure learning outcomes through standardized assessments. Extensive RCT evidence demonstrates effectiveness.

name: School Feeding Programs
evidence_text: Daily nutritious meals provided to school children improving attendance, learning outcomes, and addressing hunger. Evidence shows school feeding increases enrollment and reduces absenteeism, particularly for girls. Addresses short-term hunger and long-term nutrition. Meals cost $0.15-0.50 per child per day. Uses local food sourcing supporting local economies. Government partnership model for sustainability and scale. Focus on areas with high food insecurity.
transparency_notes: Programs track meal delivery, attendance rates, and enrollment. Nutrition assessments measure impact on child health.

name: Maternal Syphilis Screening Programs
evidence_text: Testing and treatment of pregnant women for syphilis preventing congenital transmission, stillbirths, and neonatal complications. Maternal syphilis causes 200,000+ stillbirths and neonatal deaths annually. Testing and penicillin treatment is highly effective and cost-effective. Integrated into antenatal care services. Addresses testing kit stockouts and supply chain issues. WHO recommends universal screening but coverage remains low (~50% globally).
transparency_notes: Programs track testing rates, treatment coverage, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Monitoring identifies supply chain gaps.

name: Schistosomiasis Control Programs
evidence_text: Mass drug administration targeting schistosomiasis (snail fever) parasitic infection in school-age children and at-risk adults. Prevents organ damage (bladder, liver, intestines) and improves health and educational outcomes. Praziquantel is safe, effective, single-dose treatment. WHO recommends annual or biannual treatment in endemic areas. Treatment costs ~$0.50 per person. School-based delivery platform. Programs aim for 75% coverage to reduce transmission.
transparency_notes: National programs report treatment coverage through school records. Prevalence surveys measure disease burden and program impact.

name: Soil-Transmitted Helminthiasis Treatment Programs
evidence_text: School-based deworming programs treating intestinal worm infections (roundworm, hookworm, whipworm) improving nutrition, school attendance, and cognitive development. Affects 1.5 billion people globally, mostly children. Albendazole or mebendazole treatment is safe, effective, and costs ~$0.50 per child. WHO recommends periodic treatment without individual diagnosis in endemic areas. Evidence shows improved growth and school outcomes. Long-term impacts on earnings.
transparency_notes: Programs report treatment coverage. Prevalence surveys monitor disease burden and assess program effectiveness.

name: Mass Media Health Campaigns
evidence_text: Radio and multimedia campaigns promoting evidence-based health behaviors including breastfeeding, immunization, hygiene, family planning, and care-seeking for childhood illness. Evidence from RCT in Burkina Faso showed 10% reduction in under-5 mortality. Uses social marketing and behavior change principles. Locally-produced programming in local languages. Reaches millions at low cost (~$1 per person reached). Saturation approach with frequent messaging.
transparency_notes: Programs conduct population surveys to measure behavior change. RCT provides rigorous impact evidence on mortality.

name: Comprehensive Eye Care Services
evidence_text: Integrated eye health programs including screening, treatment, surgery, and rehabilitation preventing and treating blindness. Addresses cataracts, refractive errors, trachoma, diabetic retinopathy, and glaucoma. Community outreach identifies patients in remote areas. Affordable or free services for poorest. Training eye care professionals and strengthening systems. Programs in India, Nepal, Tibet, Bangladesh, Cambodia, Africa. Restores sight and prevents blindness cost-effectively.
transparency_notes: Programs report on patients screened, surgeries performed, and visual outcomes. Quality monitoring ensures high success rates.

name: Ultra-Poverty Graduation Programs Multi-Component
evidence_text: Multi-component intervention combining asset transfers (livestock/agriculture), consumption support, savings facilitation, health interventions, and coaching to help ultra-poor households achieve sustainable livelihoods. Evidence from multiple RCTs shows large sustained impacts on income, assets, food security, and well-being. Targets households living on <$0.50/day. 18-24 month intensive support period. Focus on women-led households. Cost $400-2,000 per household depending on context.
transparency_notes: Programs collect detailed household data tracking income, assets, and well-being. Multiple RCTs across countries demonstrate impact.

name: Lead Paint Regulation Advocacy
evidence_text: Policy advocacy and technical assistance supporting governments to enact and enforce lead paint regulations. Lead exposure causes cognitive impairment in children with no safe level. Paint regulation is cost-effective prevention creating permanent infrastructure. Works with governments on legislation development, standards setting, and compliance monitoring. Estimated 800 million children globally exposed to lead. LEEP has contributed to regulations in 15+ countries protecting millions of children.
transparency_notes: LEEP publishes reports on advocacy progress, policy wins, and estimated children protected. Transparent theory of change.

name: Malaria Vaccine Rollout Support Programs
evidence_text: Technical assistance to ministries of health for integrating RTS,S and R21 malaria vaccines into national immunization programs. Supports training, community outreach, cold chain, and operational research. Malaria vaccines shown to reduce severe malaria and deaths by 30-40%. WHO recommends for children in malaria-endemic areas. Complements existing prevention tools. Programs support successful introduction and scale-up of this new intervention.
transparency_notes: Vaccine programs monitored through immunization information systems. Coverage surveys and safety monitoring conducted.

name: Tuberculosis Household Contact Management
evidence_text: Active case finding and preventive treatment (isoniazid or rifapentine) for young children (<5 years) exposed to tuberculosis in households. Reduces progression to active TB disease and death. Evidence shows preventive treatment reduces TB disease by 60-90% in exposed children. Cost-effective intervention in high-burden settings. Addresses gap in current TB programs which often miss household contacts. WHO recommends but coverage remains low.
transparency_notes: Programs track household contact tracing, testing rates, and preventive treatment initiation. Monitors for adverse events.

name: Oral Rehydration Solution Distribution
evidence_text: Community health worker delivery of oral rehydration salts (ORS) and zinc for treating childhood diarrhea preventing dehydration deaths. Diarrhea is second leading cause of death in children under 5 (500,000 deaths annually). ORS and zinc reduce diarrhea duration and severity. Evidence-based, cost-effective intervention. Low-osmolarity ORS is WHO-recommended standard. Combined with zinc, reduces mortality by 30%. CHW distribution improves access in remote areas.
transparency_notes: Programs monitor ORS and zinc distribution and usage. Household surveys measure treatment rates for diarrhea episodes.

name: Pneumonia Case Management Programs
evidence_text: Community-level diagnosis and treatment of childhood pneumonia by trained health workers using antibiotics (amoxicillin). Reduces mortality from respiratory infections, leading cause of child death (750,000 annually). CHWs equipped to assess, classify, and treat using integrated management of childhood illness (IMCI) protocols. Evidence shows CHW treatment is effective and cost-effective. Improves access in areas without health facility coverage.
transparency_notes: Programs monitor CHW caseload, treatment provision, and treatment outcomes. Quality assessments ensure appropriate care.

name: Extractive Sector Transparency Programs
evidence_text: Support for countries to join and implement Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative standards. Multi-stakeholder process improves governance and revenue management in oil, gas, and mining sectors. Evidence shows EITI reduces corruption and increases GDP. Disclosure requirements cover revenue payments, contracts, beneficial ownership. Creates permanent accountability infrastructure. 57 implementing countries. Focus on translating transparency into accountability and development outcomes.
transparency_notes: EITI implementation is transparent by design. All country reports, revenue data, and beneficial ownership published.

name: Climate-Resilient Agriculture Programs
evidence_text: Training and inputs for farmers to adapt to climate change through drought-resistant crops, agroforestry, and sustainable farming practices. Climate change threatens food security and farmer livelihoods. Programs provide climate-smart seeds (drought-tolerant maize, beans), conservation agriculture training, and water management techniques. Evidence shows improved resilience and maintained yields despite climate shocks. Combines productivity increases with risk reduction.
transparency_notes: Programs track adoption of climate-smart practices and measure resilience through yield stability analysis.

name: Agroforestry Programs
evidence_text: Tree planting initiatives integrated with farming providing timber income, diversification, environmental benefits, and climate resilience for smallholder farmers. Distributes tree seedlings (fruit, timber, fodder) with training on management. Evidence shows improved farm income, soil fertility, and carbon sequestration. Addresses deforestation and land degradation. Trees provide long-term assets and multiple income streams. Climate adaptation benefits through erosion control and microclimate improvement.
transparency_notes: Programs track tree seedling distribution, survival rates, and farmer adoption. Long-term monitoring of tree growth and benefits.

name: Market Access for Smallholders Programs
evidence_text: Linking small-scale farmers to reliable markets and fair prices through aggregation, storage, and buyer connections. Addresses exploitation by middlemen and price volatility. Programs provide market information, collective marketing, and buyer relationships. Evidence shows higher farm-gate prices and reduced post-harvest losses. Some programs include storage facilities and quality grading. Focus on maximizing farmer profitability through better marketing. Connects farmers to formal value chains.
transparency_notes: Programs track volumes marketed, prices received, and farmer income from sales. Compares to local market prices.

name: Women's Economic Empowerment Programs
evidence_text: Programs targeting women entrepreneurs with business training, credit access, and market linkages addressing gender barriers to economic participation. Evidence shows economic empowerment improves household well-being and women's agency. Addresses constraints women face including limited mobility, education, capital access, and market connections. Programs include business skills, savings groups, asset transfers, and mentoring. Focus on sustainable livelihoods and economic independence.
transparency_notes: Programs measure business outcomes, income changes, and women's empowerment indicators. Some programs have RCT evidence.

name: Kangaroo Mother Care Programs
evidence_text: Skin-to-skin contact intervention for low-birthweight and preterm newborns improving thermoregulation, reducing mortality, and promoting breastfeeding. Evidence from multiple RCTs shows 40% mortality reduction in low-birthweight infants. Cost-effective requiring minimal equipment or infrastructure. Trains healthcare workers and establishes KMC units in government hospitals. Addresses major cause of neonatal deaths (2.4 million annually). WHO recommends for infants <2,000 grams. Focus on resource-limited settings where incubators unavailable.
transparency_notes: Programs track babies receiving KMC, weight gain, and survival outcomes. Monitoring ensures protocol adherence and quality.
